Gardens, Richmond - Self-Guided Audio Tour\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"\uD83D\uDCF1 Smartphone tickets\\\\n\\\\n\u26A1 Instant access to your tickets\\\\n\\\\n\u23F3 Duration: from 1h to 1h 15m\\\\n\\\\n\uD83D\uDC49 Experience available in English\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nEscape to Kew Gardens for an epic self-guided audio adventure in Richmond! Dive into the largest treasure trove of living plants on the planet. Wander through the enchanting Princess of Wales Conservatory, soak up the vibes in the Mediterranean Garden, and marvel at the iconic architecture and hidden delights Kew has to offer. With insights from a botanical expert, uncover the wonders of Marianne North, step into the breathtaking Temperate House, and have a blast with family-friendly activities at The Hive. It's a botanical journey not to be missed. Get your tickets for Kew Gardens, Richmond - Self-Guided Audio Tour!\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nHighlights\\\\n\\\\n\uD83C\uDF3F Explore the world's largest collection of living plants at Kew Gardens.\\\\n\uD83C\uDF3A Uncover secret gems and architectural wonders with a self-guided audio tour.\\\\n\uD83D\uDC1D Dive into family fun activities at The Hive and connect with nature.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nWhat's included?\\\\n\\\\n\u2714\uFE0F Offline Mode: Download tours in advance to listen without WiFi.\\\\n\u2714\uFE0F Location Aware: GPS map allows you to enjoy sites, without getting lost.\\\\n\u2714\uFE0F Access to your self-guided audio tour.\\\\n\u2714\uFE0F Instagram Hotspots: We find the spot for your perfect picture.\\\\n\u2714\uFE0F Audio tour narrated by a historian.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nItinerary\\\\n\\\\nMarianne North Gallery - Admission not included\\\\n\\\\nTemperate House - Admission not included\\\\n\\\\nRoyal Botanic Gardens, Kew - Admission not included\\\\n\\\\nPrincess of Wales Conservatory - Admission not included\\\\n\\\\nThe Hive - Admission not included\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nAdditional Information\\\\n\\\\n\u267F Wheelchair accessible and transportation options cater to wheelchair users.\\\\n\uD83D\uDC76 Infants and small children are welcome with prams or strollers.\\\\n\uD83D\uDE86 Nearby public transportation options are readily available.\\\\n\uD83C\uDFCB\uFE0F\u200D\u2642\uFE0F Suitable for individuals of all physical fitness levels.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nWhy choose Fever?\\\\n\\\\n\u2714\uFE0F Millions of users book every month.\\\\n\\\\n\u2714\uFE0F The best prices and availability at all times.\\\\n\\\\n\u2714\uFE0F Thousands of unique experiences.\\\\n\\\\n\u2714\uFE0F Verified user reviews.\\\\n\\\\n\u2714\uFE0F 24\\/7 customer service.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nExperience supplied by Vidi Guides\\\\n\\\\nAll ticket sales are final and cannot be refunded, exchanged, or otherwise modified. Click here to check out the T&Cs.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.4787438,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.295573},\\\"price\\\":{\\\"currencyCode\\\":\\\"GBP\\\"},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/contemporary-art-gallery-.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441257\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441257\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"The Harmony Test\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Alice Hamilton directs this new play by Richard Molloy about a pair of couples: newlyweds Zoe and Kash, who are planning to start a family and are intent on doing so \u2018correctly\u2019; and Naomi and Charlie, who\u2019ve been married for 20 years \u2013 him happily, her less so. It\u2019s got an excellent cast of Pearl Chanda, Bally Gill, Jemima Rooper, Sandro Rosta and Milo Twomey.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.542875,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.1733},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_theater_15.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441279\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441279\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Matthew Krishanu: \u2018The Bough Breaks\u2019\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Matthew Krishanu\u2019s work is shrouded in the fog of memory. Across a series of dreamy, washed-out paintings, he digs up his past and recasts it in canvas and paper.\\\\nTwo boys recur throughout most of the show, the artist and his brother as kids. They sit on boats and horses, swim in rivers and seas, clamber over a Henry Moore sculpture. The works look like family snapshots, faded photos of holidays and daytrips that have been painted from memory. It\u2019s as if painting these moments will somehow bring them back, make them real, permanent.\\\\nIn the most striking works here the boys sit on the vast drooping branches of a huge banyan tree. They\u2019re dwarfed by it, lost in this enormous symbol of India. The paint is dripping down the canvas, leaching away, the memories are fading.\\\\nAll this water and greenery is a legacy. In other works his daughter and late wife climb a tree in Epping Forest, or stare out onto an Essex pond. In water and trees is where these memories, these pasts, coalesce into something tangible, long after they\u2019re gone.\\\\nThe final series of paintings shows Christian churches, priests, nuns and congregations in India and Bangladesh. Krishanu\u2019s mother was a theologian, his father a British missionary. These images are crisper, sharper, firmer than the rest; no fog or haze here, just stark personal history.\\\\nThere\u2019s a temptation to read the Christian works as a comment on religion as a colonising force, or a kickback against the dominance of the white figure in Christian aesthetics. Maybe, but I'm not sure. Instead, they feel like an extension of Krishanu\u2019s excavation of memory, a way of processing the mental images of his past.\\\\nNot all the paintings here are good, some are actually pretty bad, and hazy nostalgic figurative painting has been absolutely everywhere for absolutely ages. But Krishanu\u2019s work is imbued with a deep, soft vulnerability, a tenderness and sadness that just about sets it apart; it\u2019s like watching him trying desperately to hold on to memories, ideas, identities, images that remain, no matter what he does, totally ungraspable.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.551251,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.183484},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_painting_0.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441284\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441284\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Plumm\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.5009706,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.1779641},\\\"price\\\":{\\\"currencyCode\\\":\\\"GBP\\\"},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/event\\/13-06-09_rar_clutch_neil_fallon_10.jpeg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441301\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441301\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Full Gas Spring Cup Series Event #1\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Full Gas returns to Hillingdon Cycle Circuit for the Sunday morning Spring Cup Series for the third year! Online entries will close at midnight on the Friday before the event and once accepted, entries cannot be transferred or refunded. Entries will also be available on the day space permitting.\\\\n\\\\nPROVISIONAL SCEDULE\\\\n08:30 - 09:05 - Masters 50+ Sign on09:15 - Masters 50+ Race Start (40 mins + 5 laps)\\\\n09:15 - 10:00 - Masters 40+ Sign on 10:15 - Masters 40+ Race Start (40 mins + 5 laps)\\\\n10:15 - 11:00 - 2\\/3\\/4 Category Sign on 11:15 - 2\\/3\\/4 Category Race Start (40 mins + 5 laps)\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.510704,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.4010437},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_cycling_5.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441320\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441320\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Minority Report\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"\u2018Minority Report\u2019 is now best known for the action-packed 2002 Spielberg sci-fi movie starring Tom Cruise. That was, in fact, a sexed-up adaptation of Philip K Dick\u2019s dystopian 1958 novella, which played out more like a Cold War thriller than the hovercar-tastic excesses of the film. Nonetheless, its central vision remained the same: a future in which criminals are arrested before they commit a crime thanks to the efforts of seemingly infallible telepaths.\\\\nDavid Haig\u2019s adaptation promises to cleave more closely to the book. But it looks like it will still be very much its own thing, with a new setting, characters and possibly even premise as it follows Dame Julia Anderton, the founder of the Pre-Crime programme, who receives a report saying she will commit a murder.\\\\nTelepaths are not mentioned in the copy, which raises the distinct possibility that in Haig\u2019s adaptation the Pre-Crime division is actually based on AI \u2013 something already being discussed as a possibility IRL.\\\\nMax Webster directs this eye-catching opener to the Lyric Hammersmith\u2019s 2024 season, a co-production with Nottingham Playhouse and Birmingham Rep with a cast TBC.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.4929,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.2268},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_theater_31.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441455\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441455\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"AEW All In\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Ticket listings for AEW - All Elite Wrestling at Wembley Stadium on Sun. B. Shelley\u2019s Poetic Reflections on Wordsworth\\\\n\\\\nA lecture by Professor Mark Sandy.\\\\n\\\\nTaking place on the eve of The Shelley Conference, this lecture focuses on some of Shelley\u2019s better-known poems collected in Mary Shelley\u2019s 'Posthumous Poems' (1824) and their imaginative response to the poetry of Wordsworth. Shelley as a poet is drawn repeatedly to those clusters of images (celestial bodies mirrored in water, evanescent rainbows, a fading rose or the burnished glow of the sun), which trace out, in Wordsworth\u2019s \u2018Ode: Intimations of Immortality\u2019, a profound loss of the \u2018visionary gleam\u2019 and sources of possible recompense. Shelley may subject Wordsworth\u2019s hopeful vision to scrutiny, but Shelley\u2019s 'Alastor' and \u2018Two Spirits \u2013 An Allegory\u2019 continue to find an imaginative resourcefulness in Wordsworth\u2019s poetic vision. This fascination with Wordsworth persists even in Shelley\u2019s last poetic fragment, 'The Triumph of Life', where Wordsworth\u2019s \u2018celestial light\u2019 and that of \u2018common day\u2019 become, for Shelley, a \u2018darkness [that] reillumines\u2019 and obliterates reality.\\\\n\\\\nMark Sandy is Professor in the Department of English Studies at Durham University. He has published extensively on Romantic poetry and its legacies, including the monographs 'Poetics of Self and Form in Keats and Shelley' (2005) and 'Romanticism, Memory, and Mourning' (2013; reprinted, 2019). He has also curated a series of edited collections on Romantic echoes from the nineteenth century to the present day, decadence, Venice and, most recently, the spectral: 'Ghostly Encounters: Cultural and Imaginary Representations of the Spectral from the Nineteenth Century to the Present' (2021), co-edited with Stefano Cracolici. He is currently the editor of 'The Review' for the British Association of Romantic Studies. He held a three-month Research Fellowship at the Armstrong Browning Library (Baylor University, Texas) during spring 2022. His latest monograph, 'Transatlantic Transformations of Romanticism: Aesthetics, Subjectivity and the Environment', was published in 2021. He is currently co-editing a four-volume set on 'Loss, Memory, and Mourning' (forthcoming, 2024) and researching a book-length study, provisionally, titled 'Spectral Presences in Romantic and Victorian Poetry: From Wordsworth to the Brownings'.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.555492,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.168245},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/event\\/shutterstock_1518192602.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6442044\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6442044\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Pure Indian Cooking\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Indian food is something you\u2019ll frequently find in London and the rest of England and this place is definitely a must when you\u2019re craving some. Pure Indian Cooking prides itself in being a family run restaurant with impeccable credentials. Husband and wife are the team \u2013Faheem Vanoo and Shiipa Dandekar\u2013 and they both started their careers with the famed Taj group in India.\\\\nThis place was established in 2015 and ever since they serve incredible dishes for you to taste. When it closed on the West End in 2002, it seemed questionable whether it was ever likely to come back. But a candle has been kept burning via a purpose-built theatre in the town of Bochum, Germany, which has played host to a production of the musical since 1988, and which Webber has used as a sort of lab to make tweaks to the show over the years (including adding a train called \u2018Brexit\u2019 a few years back).\\\\nThe Bochum edition is probably a reasonable heads-up as to what to expect for this new UK production, which will convert the Troubadour Theatre in Wembley Park into the Starlight Auditorium and what we\u2019re promised will be an \u2018immersive\u2019 take on the show directed byLuke Sheppard of \u2018& Juliet\u2019 fame. Entry is free, but all your well-spent cash will be going to some very worthy causes \u2013 last year raised more than \u00A322,000 for local charities like Richmond Food Bank and the Riverbank Trust.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.479505,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.289116},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_food_and_drinks_5.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441168\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441168\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Windsor\\\",\\\"shortDescription\\\":\\\"Visit Windsor Castle, residence of Queen Elizabeth, and explore Windsor's attractions like the Royal Shopping Center, Eaton College, and Legoland Windsor.\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"If you\u2019re visiting Windsor, you definitely have to go to the main attraction of the city, its castle, built in 1080 by King William the Conqueror. It has been the residence of many monarchs of the English crown through the centuries, and today it is usually the place of residence of Queen Elizabeth, at least on weekends. The view inside the castle is highly recommended. \\\\r\\\\nAmong other places of interest to know on your visit to Windsor it's the the Windsor Royal Shopping Center, a real spectacle; stroll through its galleries where you will find shops, restaurants and the tourist information office.\\\\r\\\\nEaton College is also a great location to visit as well as the Windsor Great Park from where you can enjoy great views of Windsor Castle and where you can get something to it since it\u2019s surrounded by a wide range of restaurants and cafes. If you\u2019re traveling with kids, don\u2019t forget to go to Legoland Windsor theme park. \\\\r\\\\nFor more information on schedules and prices, consult its official website.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.48172789999998,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.613576},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/shutterstock_1340467745.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441349\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441349\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Fangirls\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Aussie writer and performer Yve Blake scored a cult domestic smash in the immediate pre-pandemic era with \u2018Fangirls\u2019 (aka \u2018FANGIRLS\u2019), a subversive musical that she wrote the book, lyrics and music for, and even initially starred in.\\\\nInspired by interviews with actual pop star fangirls, the musical follows Edna, a 14-year-old Australian girl madly in love with one \u2018Harry\u2019, a member of a massive-selling pop group (hmm, rings a bell). When the band comes to Sydney she\u2019s determined to meet Harry \u2013 at any cost.\\\\nAlthough it seems probable it will be substantially or totally recast, this is, nonetheless, a London remounting of the original production, headed by Australian director Paige Rattray.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.4929,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.2268},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/young-couple-dancing-water.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441448\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441448\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Shrek the Musical\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"This review is from 2011; \u2018Shrek\u2019 returns to London in the summer of 2023 as a touring production, with a completely different cast.\\\\nIf DreamWorks is going to emulate Disney's success in turning animated kids' movies into live musicals, it needs to find its own Alan Menken. Animations like 'Shrek' or 'How to Train Your Dragon' are lustier, crustier and so much funnier than Disney's classics. But the soul of any stage musical is in its music. It's a shame Neil Diamond wasn't available for the whole job in DreamWorks's first live project: a foot-stamping, all-cast rendition of 'I'm a Believer' ends this jolly green giant of a show on an infectious high which the previous 17 numbers can't quite reach.\\\\nJason Moore and Rob Ashford's improved ex-Broadway production takes 'Shrek's freak-championing generosity of spirit and hammers it home, with a chorus of overweight pigs, wicked witches and other fairytale misfits. But Jeanine Tesori's bland, wistful music, despite soulful moments of '60s pastiche and a witty book and lyrics from David Lindsay-Abaire, just isn't juicy enough to do 'Shrek' justice.\\\\nWilliam Steig's story of an ogre who falls for a princess farts in the face of fairytale conventions. That helps make 'Shrek' a better show for kids than the spectacular but overly sadistic 'Wizard of Oz' currently at the Palladium. If parents can afford to take them, children will love the belching, irreverence and storybook lustre of Tim Hatley's costumes and design. The high point is a certain dragon (voiced tremendously by Landi Oshinowo). Since Broadway she has learned to fly, and circles over our heads to defend her objet d'amour, Shrek's talking Donkey.\\\\nI warmed to Nigel Lindsay's gentle Shrek, stumping wistfully around in pounds of sacking and latex. Amanda Holden's Princess Fiona brings a nice neurotic sharp edge to numbers such as 'I Think I Got You Beat', where Shrek and Fiona, each abandoned at seven, squabble over who had the worse childhood (the show wittily adds their backstories). But Holden's tap-dancing Fiona is more proficient than appealing. And Richard Blackwood's Donkey is doomed to hee-haw in the shadow of Eddie Murphy's voiceover.\\\\nThe hilarious star is Nigel Harman. As dastardly mini-villain Lord Farquaad, he spends most of the show on his knees, doing mind-bogglingly lubricious dance and exercise routines with the aid of a pair of fake little yellow-stockinged legs, which have to be seen to be believed. Post-'EastEnders', Harman has done plenty of meritorious straight theatre (Pinter's 'Caretaker', Richard Greenberg's 'Three Days of Rain'). But it's here as a vertically challenged camp tyrant with delusions of Olivier's Richard III that he truly expresses himself.\\\\nStaged, Steig's twisted fairy tale looks a lot like panto. 'Shrek' has had plenty creative TLC and cash poured in since it closed early on Broadway. Its producers obviously believe that London, with its broader, less reverent musical tastes, will love the ogre - and they may be right. After all, we do have a very long annual history of falling for camp fairytale pastiches featuring fart There will then be a break during August with 3 Saturday races running in September.\\\\nRace format will follow the same format as last year, a 4th category and separate women's race to start at 6.30 p.m. followed by an E\\/12\\/3 event and running at the same time a 3rds only event starting at 7.10 p.m..\\\\nThis year we will be running womens races every week, the first will be a separate 4ths race, the 2nd will be a 2\\/3\\/4 cat race and then on alternate weeks an E\\/1\\/2\\/3 and an 3\\/4 category race as we try and cater for all women categories.\\\\nE\\/1 Women are welcome to ride in the men's events on the dates when the 3\\/4 races are being run.\\\\nAll West Thames affiliated riders will score points if finishing in the top 10 and we will be running a league competition for WT members with sponsorship from Miche ensuring that the top riders in both the mens and womens league will be well rewarded at the prize presentation which takes place after the last nights Tuesday races.\\\\nPre race entry fees are WT members \u00A313 and non members \u00A318\\\\nEntry on the day will be WT members \u00A320 or \u00A325 non members\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.510704,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.4010437},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_cycling_0.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441449\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441449\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Accordion Fields\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"A group exhibition of cross-generational painters, 'Accordion Fields' presents a selection of works across both of Lisson Gallery\u2019s London spaces. All eight artists, whether born or based in the UK or internationally, initially cultivated their artistic talent in London, studying at one of the city\u2019s prominent arts schools and often in direct dialogue with one another. Across a thirty-year span, the artists have witnessed a multiplicity of socio-political shifts, including London\u2019s evolving relationship with the rest of the UK, Europe and the world, and an evolution in the position of British painting on a global stage. With works in the show spanning densely layered landscapes to compressed portraits and composite re-imaginings of past events, the participating artists together produce a symphony of painterly styles, exploring the indeterminate, liminal and multi-dimensional notions of space.\\\\n\\\\nThe title of the exhibition, Accordion Fields, expresses the very nature of expansion and compression: geographically, as many of the artists have either returned to or moved away from London, and compositionally, with the artists\u2019 specific awareness of, and different approaches to, depicting space or a place. Conceived through a variety of approaches, depicted space within the stretcher is folded, tilted, layered, and peeled away so that depth perception is confused and deferred. In the paintings of Varda Caivano, Sarah Cunningham, Pam Evelyn and Tim Stoner, imagery is often pressed toward the surface of the picture plane, so that an ambiguity between what is representational or abstract space occurs. Elsewhere, figures and forms seen from ambiguous viewpoints are left untethered in disorientating expanses, with undefined borders, such as in the work of Andrew Pierre Hart and Elinor Stanley. In the figuration of Dexter Dalwood and Joseph Yaeger we witness the re-presenting of historical facts and the examination of found imagery. Positioning visual information \u2018out of time\u2019, these painters imbue their works with complex coded narratives and psychological tension.\\\\n\\\\nAccordion Fields features work that draws inspiration from a wide array of cultural and historical disciplines, from painters across art history \u2013 David Bomberg, Helen Frankenthaler, Joan Mitchell and Willem de Kooning \u00AC\u2013 to diverse genres of music and cinematography. Rather than confining their attention to one identity or geopolitical space, or moulding into a movement or neat composition, these eight artists embrace timeless and universal themes that seek to recognise not just their own existence but that of the human spirit, providing these paintings the opportunity to connect with audiences past, present and future.\\\\n\\\\nOther presentations by artists in Accordion Fields include Andrew Pierre Hart\u2019s exhibition, 'Bio-Data Flows and Other Rhythms \u2013 A Local Story' at Whitechapel Gallery (opening February 2024), Varda Caivano at Labor, Mexico City (February 2024), Dexter Dalwood debuting his first solo show with Lisson Gallery in London (September 2024), Elinor Stanley in the group exhibition at Nova Contemporary, Bangkok (May 2024), and Joseph Yaeger at Antenna Space, Shanghai (November 2024).\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.5211047,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.1681336},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/33875371415_161566dee6_z.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441499\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441499\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Brian Wright Junior Mens and U23\\/Junior Womens Circuit Races\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Junior Mens and U23\\/Junior Womens circuit races, which will also serve as the inaugural Slipstreamers Academy Junior Club Championships road races.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n13:30 Race 1: U23\\/JNR Womens race (full circuit, 55 minutes plus 5 laps)\\\\n15:00 Race 2: JNR Open race (full circuit, 1h10min plus 5 laps)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nAll races are run under British Cycling rules and regulations\\\\n\\\\nRacers who do not have a full BC race licence are welcome to race but will need to pay a fee on the day for a day race licence. Please see BC webpage for further information - Single day racing licences: road, track and cyclo-cross (britishcycling.org.uk)\\\\n\\\\nU16s with dispensation are welcome to ride.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.510704,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.4010437},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_cycling_2.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441558\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441558\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"South BMX Regional Series 2024 - Explore royal history, Queen Victoria's childhood rooms, and Princess Diana's fashion.\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Kensington Palace is a royal residence, located in the gardens of the same name and it\u2019s the current home of \u200B\u200B The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their children. It is considered a palace of secret stories and public lives and has been a place influenced by generations of royal women. In it several members of the British royalty have lived, as did Princess Diana of Wales, until the day she died. \\\\r\\\\nCome to this incredible place and experience life as an 18th-century royal courtier while you make your way through the King\u2019s and Queen\u2019s state Apartments decorated with paintings from the Royal Collection. Walk around the very rooms where Queen Victoria lived as a child as you get to know more about her life as a monarch, a mother, a wife and a woman. You can also get to know Diana\u2019s fashion story with an exhibition of her style.\\\\r\\\\nFor more information on schedules and prices, consult its official website.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.50537,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.18842},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/place\\/shutterstock_1029254164.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441277\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441277\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Acis and Galatea at Opera Holland Park\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Immerse yourself in the breathtaking architecture of London's Opera Holland Park Theatre for a concert that will awaken your understanding of opera.\\\\n\\\\nA new production by Opera Holland Park, English libretto by John Gay, surtitles in English. With the City of London Sinfonia and the Opera Holland Park Chorus.\\\\n\\\\nA miniature masterpiece of love, loss, and transformation. Composed in 1718 for private performance in the gardens of the Duke of Chandos\u2019s palace, Handel\u2019s tragicomic serenata is a beautiful story of love, loss, and transformation. The music is filled with birdsong and murmuring waters as the sea nymph Galatea and the shepherd Acis celebrate their love, enraging the lustful cyclops, Polyphemus. When Polyphemus attacks Acis, the shepherd is transformed into a natural spring, forever part of the idyllic landscape and the tears of his beloved nymph.\\\\n\\\\nLouise Bakker directs Opera Holland Park\u2019s first production of a Handel opera. Former Opera Holland Park Young Artist and alumnus of the Royal Opera\u2019s Jette Parker scheme Michael Papadopoulos conducts, with Anthony Gregory and Elizabeth Karani as the lovers, Acis and Galatea. South African bass\u2010baritone Chuma Sijeqa takes on the role of Polyphemus, the cyclops driven mad by unrequited passion.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.502433,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.202219},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/22678402502_f02032f216_z.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441379\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441379\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"The World of Tim Burton\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"The fantastical and \u2018comically grotesque\u2019 world of Tim Burton, the esteemed gothic, fantastical director behind the likes of \u2018Beetlejuice\u2019, \u2018Edward Scissorhands\u2019 and \u2018Dark Shadows\u2019, is being put under the spotlight in this Design Museum exhibition. If you\u2019re keen to know more about his distinctive aesthetic, but also about his work as an illustrator, photographer and author, you\u2019re headed to the right place.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.4980407,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.1980116},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/event\\/5136965553_21c14017b0_c.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441414\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441414\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Film Music Gala\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"A brand new program awaits you, dedicated entirely to the music of your favorite hero and superhero films \u2013 all performed within the magnificent surroundings of the Royal Albert Hall.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nFeaturing timeless themes from Batman, The Avengers, Superman, Gladiator, Harry Potter, Indiana Jones, Star Wars\u00AE, The Lord of the Rings\u2026 and many more.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.50090879999999,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.17736600000000033},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/event\\/brian-mcgowan-2qkhvko2caa-unsplash.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441454\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441454\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Enzo Mari at the Design Museum\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Italian artist Enzo Mari\u2019s simple but ingenious designs have inspired generations of creative types. This retrospective at the Design Museum is a comprehensive showcase of his resonant and timeless projects. The exhibition debuted at Triennale Milano in 2020 \u2013 shortly after Mari\u2019s death \u2013 and spans his 60-year career, bringing together furniture, product design, children's books and conceptual installations, all skillfully curated by Hans Ulrich Obrist with Francesca Giacomelli.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.4980407,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.1980116},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_exhibition_6.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441782\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441782\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Ghostbusters in Concert\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"\uD83D\uDCF1 Smartphone tickets\\\\n\\\\n\u26A1 Instant access to your tickets\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nHighlights\\\\n\\\\n\uD83C\uDFA4 The beloved \u201880s sci-fi comedy will join the Royal Albert Hall\u2019s Films in Concert series to celebrate the movie\u2019s 40th anniversary.\\\\n\\\\n\u2728 Watch Ivan Reitman\u2019s original 1984 classic on the big screen whilst Elmer Bernstein\u2019s famous score is performed live by a full orchestra.\\\\n\\\\n\uD83C\uDFB6 Enjoy a night out in town and watch Ghostbusters in Concert live.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nThe Show\\\\n\\\\n'Who you gonna call?' Watch Ivan Reitman\u2019s original 1984 classic on the big screen at Halloween - all whilst Elmer Bernstein\u2019s famous score is performed live by a full orchestra conducted by Peter Bernstein. As with \u2018Great Expectations\u2019 the vibe is more serious than silly, but Izzard is a charismatic enough performer that comedy fans ought to have a good time (though being familiar with the play can\u2019t hurt).\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.488683,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.227079},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_comedy_8.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441385\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441385\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Revised Edition\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"HackelBury Fine Art, London, presents Coral Woodbury\u2019s second solo exhibition, Revised Edition, featuring new work from three series, all inspired by the form and substance of the book. Woodbury uses recurring motifs such as ashes, palimpsests, and remnants of material culture to evoke themes of absence and memory, and bridge human connection across time.\\\\n\\\\nIn her series, Revised Edition, Woodbury enacts a feminist intervention in the art history canon. On pages torn from the seminal Janson\u2019s History of Art \u2013 which entirely omitted artist women from its first 29 printings \u2013 she, with sumi ink, paints women back into the history which excluded them. Her work renders the invisible visible.\\\\n\\\\n\u201CWhen complete, Revised Edition will encompass 617 paintings and will stand as testimony against the erasure of others which reaches deeply into our culture.\u201D\\\\n\\\\nOil paintings from the Broken Spine series continue this same exploration of the vagaries of memory, time, and history. Translucent layers of paint and obscured writing lend an ephemeral quality which suggests the fading, forgetting, and fragmenting of the past. From parchment manuscripts, to authors\u2019 galley proofs, to the current US book banning epidemic \u2014 the traces and erasures of thought become part of the process of painting.\\\\n\\\\n\u201CThese paintings originated when I was recovering from a fractured spine. Themes of brokenness and repair entered my work, and I began exploring the metaphorical connections between book and body.\u201D\\\\n\\\\nThe series In Place is Woodbury\u2019s personal travelogue, noted in colour rather than writing. Finding a timeworn book specific to the location has become an orienting ritual upon arrival. The pages, swatched in various hues of gouache, record fleeting experiences in the language of color.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.49869,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.18511},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/33490569390_d1523ece91_z.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441399\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441399\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Barbie\u00AE: The Exhibition\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"2023 was the year of Barbie mania, but 2024 is the year of the Barbie exhibition. Its intimate stage has witnessed the performances of renowned jazz and soul artists, including Bobby Womack, Amy Winehouse, Adele, D'Angelo, and many others. Originally an old branch of Barclays, the venue exudes a unique charm and character that adds to the overall experience.\\\\n\\\\nthe music:\\\\nThe Alehouse Sessions \u2013 curated and devised by Bjarte Eike \u2013 is an ever changing and evolving insight into the music of the English 17th century tavern. It gives audiences a window into this tumultuous period through Purcell overtures, English sea shanties, and Scandinavian folk songs thrown in for good measure.\\\\n\\\\nThis diversion from the traditional concert model is what is at the heart of the Sessions. Through the medium of these well\u2010loved tunes, a story of the period is interwoven into the music making creating a unique environment between audience and performer. Alison Langer shines as Nedda, Canio's disillusioned spouse, while Harry Thatcher portrays her ill\u2010fated lover, Silvio. Immerse yourself in the world of these timeless operatic masterpieces at this must\u2010see event.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.502433,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.202219},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/5848766054_0c9b7fd2e4_z.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441348\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441348\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Yinka Shonibare CBE: \u2018Suspended States\u2019\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Britain is littered with symbols of death and exploitation; not hidden away shamefully, but raised up, celebrated and gloried. Public sculptures of controversial historical figures are everywhere, and now they\u2019re in the Serpentine too, because Yinka Shonibare CBE has put them there.\\\\r\\\\nThe Nigerian-British art megastar has filled the gallery with recreations of statues of Churchill, Kitchener, Queen Victoria and Clive of India. But they\u2019re scaled down, their power diminished, minimised, undermined. They\u2019re puny now, smaller than you, weak. And of course, they\u2019re covered in Shonibare\u2019s signature Dutch wax print (colourful fabric inspired by Indonesian printing traditions, traded by the Dutch, ubiquitous in Africa, and now used by Shonibare as visual shorthand for the complex history of colonialism).\\\\r\\\\nThis is what Yinka Shonibare CBE \u2013 that Commander of the British Empire title matters \u2013 does, what he\u2019s always done: highlight, tear apart and subvert the legacy of British imperialism with directness, colour and wit. The debate around public statues of figures like Churchill and Clive \u2013 whose accomplishments came at a terrible human cost, who caused so much pain to the people over whom they ruled \u2013 has been raging for years now, and it feels like the flames of its anger abated a while ago. But Shonibare\u2019s installation is a clever, almost joyful reappropriation of historical pain, injustice and trauma.\\\\r\\\\nIt makes for grim if colourful viewing\\\\r\\\\nShonibare has filled the central gallery with architectural models of places of sanctuary \u2013 the Amnesty International offices, Tokeiji Temple in Japan which protected women fleeing domestic violence, Peter Mott House in New Jersey which was part of the Underground Railroad \u2013 a darkly atmospheric, fragile paean to the need for safety in a dangerous world. In among them is a model of the Bibby Stockholm barge, used by the UK government to hold asylum seekers in cramped, dirty, unsafe conditions. Maybe not all places of refuge are what they seem.\\\\r\\\\nThe final work is a library of books about war from throughout history, all rebound in Dutch wax print. Shonibare is forcing us to ask who writes history, whose perspective is elevated above others, whose lives are worth more, what matters? It makes for grim if colourful viewing.\\\\r\\\\nThe works on canvas here are not his strong suit, and the timeline of his GAS artist residency program is a missed opportunity to amplify the artists he\u2019s done so well to support over the years. And though the rest of the show is good, you can\u2019t help feeling that it\u2019s the exact same idea he\u2019s been churning out for decades. There\u2019s nothing new here, but if you had an idea this good you\u2019d probably overdo it too.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.50479,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.174983},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/14123868744_9e627220dc_z.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441496\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441496\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Neil Warnock Live\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.503509999999984,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.22384000000000476},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_concert_14.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441553\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441553\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Otobong Nkanga\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"For her inaugural exhibition with Lisson Gallery since joining last year, Otobong Nkanga returns to the process of drawing at both large and small scales, revisiting an area of foundational importance to her practice, which is rooted in the connections between thinking, performing and making. Drawing functions both as site of exploration and as cementation of her wider iconography as an artist, featuring bodies, landscapes and abstract passages, as well as the ecological and cosmological subject matters that spin out into the rest of the work. From this starting point, she reveals new sculptural objects, including stacked and striated columns of ceramic vessels (produced for a major solo show in Spain last year) as well as wall-hung and floor-based works that combine rope, glass, oils and tactile materials into personal, scented talismans.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.5211047,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.1681336},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/14143618843_d0d24523cb_z.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"}],\\\"meta\\\":{\\\"count\\\":110,\\\"links\\\":{\\\"self\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities?longitude=-0.44161&radius=50&latitude=51.57285\\\"}}},\\\"attributes\\\":{\\\"headers\\\":{\\\"date\\\":\\\"Thu, 26 Dec 2024 13:25:15 GMT\\\",\\\"content-type\\\":\\\"application\\/vnd.amadeus+json\\\",\\\"transfer-encoding\\\":\\\"chunked\\\",\\\"connection\\\":\\\"keep-alive\\\",\\\"cache-control\\\":\\\"no-cache, no-store, max-age=0, must-revalidate\\\",\\\"expires\\\":\\\"0\\\",\\\"pragma\\\":\\\"no-cache\\\",\\\"referrer-policy\\\":\\\"no-referrer-when-downgrade\\\",\\\"strict-transport-security\\\":\\\"max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains\\\",\\\"vary\\\":\\\"Accept-Encoding\\\",\\\"x-content-type-options\\\":\\\"nosniff\\\",\\\"x-frame-options\\\":\\\"DENY\\\",\\\"x-xss-protection\\\":\\\"1; mode=block\\\",\\\"ama-gateway-request-id\\\":\\\"rrt-095584195de5afc6a-a-de-3641027-496554863-1\\\",\\\"access-control-allow-headers\\\":\\\"origin, x-requested-with, accept, Content-Type, Authorization\\\",\\\"access-control-max-age\\\":\\\"3628800\\\",\\\"access-control-allow-methods\\\":\\\"*\\\",\\\"server\\\":\\\"Amadeus\\\",\\\"access-control-allow-origin\\\":\\\"*\\\"},\\\"reasonPhrase\\\":\\\"OK\\\",\\\"statusCode\\\":200}}}"}

Gardens, Richmond - Self-Guided Audio Tour\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"\uD83D\uDCF1 Smartphone tickets\\\\n\\\\n\u26A1 Instant access to your tickets\\\\n\\\\n\u23F3 Duration: from 1h to 1h 15m\\\\n\\\\n\uD83D\uDC49 Experience available in English\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nEscape to Kew Gardens for an epic self-guided audio adventure in Richmond! Dive into the largest treasure trove of living plants on the planet. Wander through the enchanting Princess of Wales Conservatory, soak up the vibes in the Mediterranean Garden, and marvel at the iconic architecture and hidden delights Kew has to offer. With insights from a botanical expert, uncover the wonders of Marianne North, step into the breathtaking Temperate House, and have a blast with family-friendly activities at The Hive. It\u2019s got an excellent cast of Pearl Chanda, Bally Gill, Jemima Rooper, Sandro Rosta and Milo Twomey.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.542875,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.1733},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_theater_15.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441279\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441279\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Matthew Krishanu: \u2018The Bough Breaks\u2019\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Matthew Krishanu\u2019s work is shrouded in the fog of memory. Across a series of dreamy, washed-out paintings, he digs up his past and recasts it in canvas and paper.\\\\nTwo boys recur throughout most of the show, the artist and his brother as kids. They sit on boats and horses, swim in rivers and seas, clamber over a Henry Moore sculpture. The works look like family snapshots, faded photos of holidays and daytrips that have been painted from memory. It\u2019s as if painting these moments will somehow bring them back, make them real, permanent.\\\\nIn the most striking works here the boys sit on the vast drooping branches of a huge banyan tree. They\u2019re dwarfed by it, lost in this enormous symbol of India. The paint is dripping down the canvas, leaching away, the memories are fading.\\\\nAll this water and greenery is a legacy. In other works his daughter and late wife climb a tree in Epping Forest, or stare out onto an Essex pond. In water and trees is where these memories, these pasts, coalesce into something tangible, long after they\u2019re gone.\\\\nThe final series of paintings shows Christian churches, priests, nuns and congregations in India and Bangladesh. Krishanu\u2019s mother was a theologian, his father a British missionary. These images are crisper, sharper, firmer than the rest; no fog or haze here, just stark personal history.\\\\nThere\u2019s a temptation to read the Christian works as a comment on religion as a colonising force, or a kickback against the dominance of the white figure in Christian aesthetics. Maybe, but I'm not sure. Instead, they feel like an extension of Krishanu\u2019s excavation of memory, a way of processing the mental images of his past.\\\\nNot all the paintings here are good, some are actually pretty bad, and hazy nostalgic figurative painting has been absolutely everywhere for absolutely ages. But Krishanu\u2019s work is imbued with a deep, soft vulnerability, a tenderness and sadness that just about sets it apart; it\u2019s like watching him trying desperately to hold on to memories, ideas, identities, images that remain, no matter what he does, totally ungraspable.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.551251,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.183484},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_painting_0.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441284\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441284\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Plumm\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.5009706,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.1779641},\\\"price\\\":{\\\"currencyCode\\\":\\\"GBP\\\"},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/event\\/13-06-09_rar_clutch_neil_fallon_10.jpeg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441301\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441301\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Full Gas Spring Cup Series Event #1\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Full Gas returns to Hillingdon Cycle Circuit for the Sunday morning Spring Cup Series for the third year! Nonetheless, its central vision remained the same: a future in which criminals are arrested before they commit a crime thanks to the efforts of seemingly infallible telepaths.\\\\nDavid Haig\u2019s adaptation promises to cleave more closely to the book. B. Shelley\u2019s Poetic Reflections on Wordsworth\\\\n\\\\nA lecture by Professor Mark Sandy.\\\\n\\\\nTaking place on the eve of The Shelley Conference, this lecture focuses on some of Shelley\u2019s better-known poems collected in Mary Shelley\u2019s 'Posthumous Poems' (1824) and their imaginative response to the poetry of Wordsworth. Shelley as a poet is drawn repeatedly to those clusters of images (celestial bodies mirrored in water, evanescent rainbows, a fading rose or the burnished glow of the sun), which trace out, in Wordsworth\u2019s \u2018Ode: Intimations of Immortality\u2019, a profound loss of the \u2018visionary gleam\u2019 and sources of possible recompense. Shelley may subject Wordsworth\u2019s hopeful vision to scrutiny, but Shelley\u2019s 'Alastor' and \u2018Two Spirits \u2013 An Allegory\u2019 continue to find an imaginative resourcefulness in Wordsworth\u2019s poetic vision. This fascination with Wordsworth persists even in Shelley\u2019s last poetic fragment, 'The Triumph of Life', where Wordsworth\u2019s \u2018celestial light\u2019 and that of \u2018common day\u2019 become, for Shelley, a \u2018darkness [that] reillumines\u2019 and obliterates reality.\\\\n\\\\nMark Sandy is Professor in the Department of English Studies at Durham University. He has published extensively on Romantic poetry and its legacies, including the monographs 'Poetics of Self and Form in Keats and Shelley' (2005) and 'Romanticism, Memory, and Mourning' (2013; reprinted, 2019). He has also curated a series of edited collections on Romantic echoes from the nineteenth century to the present day, decadence, Venice and, most recently, the spectral: 'Ghostly Encounters: Cultural and Imaginary Representations of the Spectral from the Nineteenth Century to the Present' (2021), co-edited with Stefano Cracolici. He is currently the editor of 'The Review' for the British Association of Romantic Studies. He held a three-month Research Fellowship at the Armstrong Browning Library (Baylor University, Texas) during spring 2022. His latest monograph, 'Transatlantic Transformations of Romanticism: Aesthetics, Subjectivity and the Environment', was published in 2021. He is currently co-editing a four-volume set on 'Loss, Memory, and Mourning' (forthcoming, 2024) and researching a book-length study, provisionally, titled 'Spectral Presences in Romantic and Victorian Poetry: From Wordsworth to the Brownings'.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.555492,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.168245},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/event\\/shutterstock_1518192602.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6442044\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6442044\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Pure Indian Cooking\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Indian food is something you\u2019ll frequently find in London and the rest of England and this place is definitely a must when you\u2019re craving some. Pure Indian Cooking prides itself in being a family run restaurant with impeccable credentials. Since then, the restaurant has amassed a strong following as a refined and very good local restaurant with many clientele calling it a London \u201CWest End restaurant in Fulham\u201D. \\\\nFor more information on reservations and prices, consult its official website.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.46947,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.209916},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/273409827_1848397655371092_6047035757237151316_n.jpeg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441192\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441192\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Abbey Road\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"I bet you can recognize this place by seeing the cover of The Beatles\u2019 album, named after it. When it closed on the West End in 2002, it seemed questionable whether it was ever likely to come back. But a candle has been kept burning via a purpose-built theatre in the town of Bochum, Germany, which has played host to a production of the musical since 1988, and which Webber has used as a sort of lab to make tweaks to the show over the years (including adding a train called \u2018Brexit\u2019 a few years back).\\\\nThe Bochum edition is probably a reasonable heads-up as to what to expect for this new UK production, which will convert the Troubadour Theatre in Wembley Park into the Starlight Auditorium and what we\u2019re promised will be an \u2018immersive\u2019 take on the show directed byLuke Sheppard of \u2018& Juliet\u2019 fame. But there\u2019s plenty more to 2024\u2019s edition of the popular afternoon, including a karate display, inflatables and a charity raffle, too. The best part? Entry is free, but all your well-spent cash will be going to some very worthy causes \u2013 last year raised more than \u00A322,000 for local charities like Richmond Food Bank and the Riverbank Trust.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.479505,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.289116},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_food_and_drinks_5.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441168\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441168\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Windsor\\\",\\\"shortDescription\\\":\\\"Visit Windsor Castle, residence of Queen Elizabeth, and explore Windsor's attractions like the Royal Shopping Center, Eaton College, and Legoland Windsor.\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"If you\u2019re visiting Windsor, you definitely have to go to the main attraction of the city, its castle, built in 1080 by King William the Conqueror. It has been the residence of many monarchs of the English crown through the centuries, and today it is usually the place of residence of Queen Elizabeth, at least on weekends. The view inside the castle is highly recommended. \\\\r\\\\nAmong other places of interest to know on your visit to Windsor it's the the Windsor Royal Shopping Center, a real spectacle; stroll through its galleries where you will find shops, restaurants and the tourist information office.\\\\r\\\\nEaton College is also a great location to visit as well as the Windsor Great Park from where you can enjoy great views of Windsor Castle and where you can get something to it since it\u2019s surrounded by a wide range of restaurants and cafes. If you\u2019re traveling with kids, don\u2019t forget to go to Legoland Windsor theme park. \\\\r\\\\nFor more information on schedules and prices, consult its official website.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.48172789999998,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.613576},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/shutterstock_1340467745.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441349\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441349\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Fangirls\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Aussie writer and performer Yve Blake scored a cult domestic smash in the immediate pre-pandemic era with \u2018Fangirls\u2019 (aka \u2018FANGIRLS\u2019), a subversive musical that she wrote the book, lyrics and music for, and even initially starred in.\\\\nInspired by interviews with actual pop star fangirls, the musical follows Edna, a 14-year-old Australian girl madly in love with one \u2018Harry\u2019, a member of a massive-selling pop group (hmm, rings a bell). When the band comes to Sydney she\u2019s determined to meet Harry \u2013 at any cost.\\\\nAlthough it seems probable it will be substantially or totally recast, this is, nonetheless, a London remounting of the original production, headed by Australian director Paige Rattray.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.4929,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.2268},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/young-couple-dancing-water.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441448\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441448\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Shrek the Musical\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"This review is from 2011; \u2018Shrek\u2019 returns to London in the summer of 2023 as a touring production, with a completely different cast.\\\\nIf DreamWorks is going to emulate Disney's success in turning animated kids' movies into live musicals, it needs to find its own Alan Menken. Animations like 'Shrek' or 'How to Train Your Dragon' are lustier, crustier and so much funnier than Disney's classics. But the soul of any stage musical is in its music. It's a shame Neil Diamond wasn't available for the whole job in DreamWorks's first live project: a foot-stamping, all-cast rendition of 'I'm a Believer' ends this jolly green giant of a show on an infectious high which the previous 17 numbers can't quite reach.\\\\nJason Moore and Rob Ashford's improved ex-Broadway production takes 'Shrek's freak-championing generosity of spirit and hammers it home, with a chorus of overweight pigs, wicked witches and other fairytale misfits. But Jeanine Tesori's bland, wistful music, despite soulful moments of '60s pastiche and a witty book and lyrics from David Lindsay-Abaire, just isn't juicy enough to do 'Shrek' justice.\\\\nWilliam Steig's story of an ogre who falls for a princess farts in the face of fairytale conventions. That helps make 'Shrek' a better show for kids than the spectacular but overly sadistic 'Wizard of Oz' currently at the Palladium. If parents can afford to take them, children will love the belching, irreverence and storybook lustre of Tim Hatley's costumes and design. The high point is a certain dragon (voiced tremendously by Landi Oshinowo). Since Broadway she has learned to fly, and circles over our heads to defend her objet d'amour, Shrek's talking Donkey.\\\\nI warmed to Nigel Lindsay's gentle Shrek, stumping wistfully around in pounds of sacking and latex. Amanda Holden's Princess Fiona brings a nice neurotic sharp edge to numbers such as 'I Think I Got You Beat', where Shrek and Fiona, each abandoned at seven, squabble over who had the worse childhood (the show wittily adds their backstories). But Holden's tap-dancing Fiona is more proficient than appealing. And Richard Blackwood's Donkey is doomed to hee-haw in the shadow of Eddie Murphy's voiceover.\\\\nThe hilarious star is Nigel Harman. As dastardly mini-villain Lord Farquaad, he spends most of the show on his knees, doing mind-bogglingly lubricious dance and exercise routines with the aid of a pair of fake little yellow-stockinged legs, which have to be seen to be believed. Post-'EastEnders', Harman has done plenty of meritorious straight theatre (Pinter's 'Caretaker', Richard Greenberg's 'Three Days of Rain'). But it's here as a vertically challenged camp tyrant with delusions of Olivier's Richard III that he truly expresses himself.\\\\nStaged, Steig's twisted fairy tale looks a lot like panto. 'Shrek' has had plenty creative TLC and cash poured in since it closed early on Broadway. Its producers obviously believe that London, with its broader, less reverent musical tastes, will love the ogre - and they may be right. After all, we do have a very long annual history of falling for camp fairytale pastiches featuring fart jokes.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.490839,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.224564},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/low-section-people-dancing-stage.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441502\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441502\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"G2 Originally an old branch of Barclays, the venue exudes a unique charm and character that adds to the overall experience.\\\\n\\\\nthe music:\\\\nFrom nineteenth\u2010century Germany to modern India, the Third Culture Collective blend entwined musical cultures. There will then be a break during August with 3 Saturday races running in September.\\\\nRace format will follow the same format as last year, a 4th category and separate women's race to start at 6.30 p.m. followed by an E\\/12\\/3 event and running at the same time a 3rds only event starting at 7.10 p.m..\\\\nThis year we will be running womens races every week, the first will be a separate 4ths race, the 2nd will be a 2\\/3\\/4 cat race and then on alternate weeks an E\\/1\\/2\\/3 and an 3\\/4 category race as we try and cater for all women categories.\\\\nE\\/1 Women are welcome to ride in the men's events on the dates when the 3\\/4 races are being run.\\\\nAll West Thames affiliated riders will score points if finishing in the top 10 and we will be running a league competition for WT members with sponsorship from Miche ensuring that the top riders in both the mens and womens league will be well rewarded at the prize presentation which takes place after the last nights Tuesday races.\\\\nPre race entry fees are WT members \u00A313 and non members \u00A318\\\\nEntry on the day will be WT members \u00A320 or \u00A325 non members\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.510704,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.4010437},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_cycling_0.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441449\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441449\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Accordion Fields\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"A group exhibition of cross-generational painters, 'Accordion Fields' presents a selection of works across both of Lisson Gallery\u2019s London spaces. All eight artists, whether born or based in the UK or internationally, initially cultivated their artistic talent in London, studying at one of the city\u2019s prominent arts schools and often in direct dialogue with one another. Across a thirty-year span, the artists have witnessed a multiplicity of socio-political shifts, including London\u2019s evolving relationship with the rest of the UK, Europe and the world, and an evolution in the position of British painting on a global stage. With works in the show spanning densely layered landscapes to compressed portraits and composite re-imaginings of past events, the participating artists together produce a symphony of painterly styles, exploring the indeterminate, liminal and multi-dimensional notions of space.\\\\n\\\\nThe title of the exhibition, Accordion Fields, expresses the very nature of expansion and compression: geographically, as many of the artists have either returned to or moved away from London, and compositionally, with the artists\u2019 specific awareness of, and different approaches to, depicting space or a place. Conceived through a variety of approaches, depicted space within the stretcher is folded, tilted, layered, and peeled away so that depth perception is confused and deferred. In the paintings of Varda Caivano, Sarah Cunningham, Pam Evelyn and Tim Stoner, imagery is often pressed toward the surface of the picture plane, so that an ambiguity between what is representational or abstract space occurs. Elsewhere, figures and forms seen from ambiguous viewpoints are left untethered in disorientating expanses, with undefined borders, such as in the work of Andrew Pierre Hart and Elinor Stanley. In the figuration of Dexter Dalwood and Joseph Yaeger we witness the re-presenting of historical facts and the examination of found imagery. Positioning visual information \u2018out of time\u2019, these painters imbue their works with complex coded narratives and psychological tension.\\\\n\\\\nAccordion Fields features work that draws inspiration from a wide array of cultural and historical disciplines, from painters across art history \u2013 David Bomberg, Helen Frankenthaler, Joan Mitchell and Willem de Kooning \u00AC\u2013 to diverse genres of music and cinematography. Rather than confining their attention to one identity or geopolitical space, or moulding into a movement or neat composition, these eight artists embrace timeless and universal themes that seek to recognise not just their own existence but that of the human spirit, providing these paintings the opportunity to connect with audiences past, present and future.\\\\n\\\\nOther presentations by artists in Accordion Fields include Andrew Pierre Hart\u2019s exhibition, 'Bio-Data Flows and Other Rhythms \u2013 A Local Story' at Whitechapel Gallery (opening February 2024), Varda Caivano at Labor, Mexico City (February 2024), Dexter Dalwood debuting his first solo show with Lisson Gallery in London (September 2024), Elinor Stanley in the group exhibition at Nova Contemporary, Bangkok (May 2024), and Joseph Yaeger at Antenna Space, Shanghai (November 2024).\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.5211047,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.1681336},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/33875371415_161566dee6_z.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441499\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441499\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Brian Wright Junior Mens and U23\\/Junior Womens Circuit Races\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Junior Mens and U23\\/Junior Womens circuit races, which will also serve as the inaugural Slipstreamers Academy Junior Club Championships road races.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n13:30 Race 1: U23\\/JNR Womens race (full circuit, 55 minutes plus 5 laps)\\\\n15:00 Race 2: JNR Open race (full circuit, 1h10min plus 5 laps)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nAll races are run under British Cycling rules and regulations\\\\n\\\\nRacers who do not have a full BC race licence are welcome to race but will need to pay a fee on the day for a day race licence. Please see BC webpage for further information - Single day racing licences: road, track and cyclo-cross (britishcycling.org.uk)\\\\n\\\\nU16s with dispensation are welcome to ride.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.510704,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.4010437},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_cycling_2.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441558\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441558\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"South BMX Regional Series 2024 - Explore royal history, Queen Victoria's childhood rooms, and Princess Diana's fashion.\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Kensington Palace is a royal residence, located in the gardens of the same name and it\u2019s the current home of \u200B\u200B The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their children. It is considered a palace of secret stories and public lives and has been a place influenced by generations of royal women. In it several members of the British royalty have lived, as did Princess Diana of Wales, until the day she died. \\\\r\\\\nCome to this incredible place and experience life as an 18th-century royal courtier while you make your way through the King\u2019s and Queen\u2019s state Apartments decorated with paintings from the Royal Collection. Walk around the very rooms where Queen Victoria lived as a child as you get to know more about her life as a monarch, a mother, a wife and a woman. You can also get to know Diana\u2019s fashion story with an exhibition of her style.\\\\r\\\\nFor more information on schedules and prices, consult its official website.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.50537,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.18842},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/place\\/shutterstock_1029254164.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441277\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441277\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Acis and Galatea at Opera Holland Park\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"Immerse yourself in the breathtaking architecture of London's Opera Holland Park Theatre for a concert that will awaken your understanding of opera.\\\\n\\\\nA new production by Opera Holland Park, English libretto by John Gay, surtitles in English. With the City of London Sinfonia and the Opera Holland Park Chorus.\\\\n\\\\nA miniature masterpiece of love, loss, and transformation. Composed in 1718 for private performance in the gardens of the Duke of Chandos\u2019s palace, Handel\u2019s tragicomic serenata is a beautiful story of love, loss, and transformation. The music is filled with birdsong and murmuring waters as the sea nymph Galatea and the shepherd Acis celebrate their love, enraging the lustful cyclops, Polyphemus. When Polyphemus attacks Acis, the shepherd is transformed into a natural spring, forever part of the idyllic landscape and the tears of his beloved nymph.\\\\n\\\\nLouise Bakker directs Opera Holland Park\u2019s first production of a Handel opera. Former Opera Holland Park Young Artist and alumnus of the Royal Opera\u2019s Jette Parker scheme Michael Papadopoulos conducts, with Anthony Gregory and Elizabeth Karani as the lovers, Acis and Galatea. As with \u2018Great Expectations\u2019 the vibe is more serious than silly, but Izzard is a charismatic enough performer that comedy fans ought to have a good time (though being familiar with the play can\u2019t hurt).\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.488683,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.227079},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/img_comedy_8.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441385\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441385\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Revised Edition\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"HackelBury Fine Art, London, presents Coral Woodbury\u2019s second solo exhibition, Revised Edition, featuring new work from three series, all inspired by the form and substance of the book. Woodbury uses recurring motifs such as ashes, palimpsests, and remnants of material culture to evoke themes of absence and memory, and bridge human connection across time.\\\\n\\\\nIn her series, Revised Edition, Woodbury enacts a feminist intervention in the art history canon. On pages torn from the seminal Janson\u2019s History of Art \u2013 which entirely omitted artist women from its first 29 printings \u2013 she, with sumi ink, paints women back into the history which excluded them. Her work renders the invisible visible.\\\\n\\\\n\u201CWhen complete, Revised Edition will encompass 617 paintings and will stand as testimony against the erasure of others which reaches deeply into our culture.\u201D\\\\n\\\\nOil paintings from the Broken Spine series continue this same exploration of the vagaries of memory, time, and history. Translucent layers of paint and obscured writing lend an ephemeral quality which suggests the fading, forgetting, and fragmenting of the past. From parchment manuscripts, to authors\u2019 galley proofs, to the current US book banning epidemic \u2014 the traces and erasures of thought become part of the process of painting.\\\\n\\\\n\u201CThese paintings originated when I was recovering from a fractured spine. Themes of brokenness and repair entered my work, and I began exploring the metaphorical connections between book and body.\u201D\\\\n\\\\nThe series In Place is Woodbury\u2019s personal travelogue, noted in colour rather than writing. Finding a timeworn book specific to the location has become an orienting ritual upon arrival. The pages, swatched in various hues of gouache, record fleeting experiences in the language of color.\\\",\\\"geoCode\\\":{\\\"latitude\\\":51.49869,\\\"longitude\\\":-0.18511},\\\"price\\\":{},\\\"pictures\\\":[\\\"https:\\/\\/cdn.smartvel.com\\/ccpictures\\/taxonomy\\/33490569390_d1523ece91_z.jpg\\\"],\\\"minimumDuration\\\":\\\"\\\"},{\\\"type\\\":\\\"activity\\\",\\\"id\\\":\\\"6441399\\\",\\\"self\\\":{\\\"href\\\":\\\"https:\\/\\/test.api.amadeus.com\\/v1\\/shopping\\/activities\\/6441399\\\",\\\"methods\\\":[\\\"GET\\\"]},\\\"name\\\":\\\"Barbie\u00AE: The Exhibition\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"2023 was the year of Barbie mania, but 2024 is the year of the Barbie exhibition. Its intimate stage has witnessed the performances of renowned jazz and soul artists, including Bobby Womack, Amy Winehouse, Adele, D'Angelo, and many others. Originally an old branch of Barclays, the venue exudes a unique charm and character that adds to the overall experience.\\\\n\\\\nthe music:\\\\nThe Alehouse Sessions \u2013 curated and devised by Bjarte Eike \u2013 is an ever changing and evolving insight into the music of the English 17th century tavern. It gives audiences a window into this tumultuous period through Purcell overtures, English sea shanties, and Scandinavian folk songs thrown in for good measure.\\\\n\\\\nThis diversion from the traditional concert model is what is at the heart of the Sessions. Through the medium of these well\u2010loved tunes, a story of the period is interwoven into the music making creating a unique environment between audience and performer. Using their own arrangement of the tunes, these \u2018Alehouse Boys\u2019 combine this unique format with humour, an unrivalled virtuosity and flare for improvisation.\\\\n\\\\nPractical Information\\\\nPlease note that all tickets to this event are standing by default. Join an evening of musical meditation, mantra, and dance at Colet House. No singing skills or beliefs required, just an open mind and willing voice.
